quick summary text.text:
• Decide you want to craft something
 • Work with your DM to confirm this is
   something you could do
 • Gather the materials you want to use
   to create the item
 • Begin crafting using the related tool
   and ability score.

Crafting Modifier = 
   your Related Tool proficiency bonus +
   your Related Ability Score modifier.

You can make progress in 2 hour
increments. For each 2 hours spent,
make a crafting roll. On a failure, no
progress is made. If you fail three times
in a row, the crafting fails and all
materials are lost. On a success, 2 hours
of progress are made. Once your
completed progress on an item is equal
to the crafting time, the item is complete.

You can "take 10" by doubling the
crafting time. Working with someone else
who has proficiency with the related tool
gives you advantage on your check, or if
you "take 10" it takes the normal
amount of time.

text: *Uses proficiency in this tool and Arcana

main text.text:
Rarely will everything you need to craft
what you want fall into your hands
without the assistance of the oldest and
most powerful tool of any craftsman:
money.
When you don't have what you need,
frequently you can buy it. For some
professions, there will be a lot more
materials that can be purchased, while
others will rely more on the other routes.

In general, the buying price of a material
is its listed value, and its selling price is
usually half of that to an interested
property. Between negotiation, market
fluctuation, and GM moods, you may
get better or worse prices. Note that
many materials are simply junk to a
party that does not have a use for them,
and will only sell to interested parties.

Purchasing is designed to be tied into the
social pillar of the game.

harvesting text.text:
Beasts, Dragons, and Monstrosities can
be harvested using Wisdom (Survival)
for meat and hides. At a GM's
discretion, a Plant type creature can be
harvested for food using the same DC
and amount, but providing common fresh
ingredients instead of meat.

Basic Harvesting takes 10 minutes. At
your GM's discretion, it may take longer
for larger creatures.

If a monster is applicable for both Basic
Harvesting and Exotic Harvesting, you
can perform both, but the second check
has disadvantage to successfully gather
the materials.

salvaging text.text:
Reagents cannot be salvaged.
A non-attuned permanent magical item
gives one essence equal to its rarity when
salvaged, which takes 2 hours and leaves
the item non-magical.

With a forge and 2 hours a metal item
can be salvaged into all its components.
Complex items can be salvaged based
on their size: Small or smaller gives 1d4
metal scraps and 1d4 parts; Medium
gives 2d6 metal scraps; Large or larger
gives 3d8 metal scraps or more.

A wooden product can be salvaged into
wood scraps equal to four times
the number of branches to create it.

text:
This process takes 4 hours, and requires
alchemist's supplies and a heat source.

A spellcaster can create 1
essence during 1 workweek; this process can't be done
faster, they are considered to have no spell slots during this.

items: 1 hide or 1 medium carapace or 2d6 scales
5 hides of 1 large carapace or 3d6 scales
10 hides or 2 large carapace or 6d6 scales
15 hides or 3 large carapace or 9d6 scales
text:
Special Materials can replace up to half of the materials harvested based on the
qualifications of the monster.
A failure gives 1d4 hide scraps, a carapace one size down, or 1/2 as many scales.

items: Harvested from a creature with AC 16 or higher
From a creature with elemental damage resistance
Armor crafted has +1 AC and Resistance to related element
text: If the difficulty modifier is not met, the material is harvested without the modifier, its special properties are ruined during harvesting.

harvesting header.header: Applicable Targets: Aberration, Constructs, Dragons, Monstrosities, Plants, Some Undead

harvesting main text.text:
A random roll is performed to judge what can be harvested from the monster. For Dragons, Giants, and Monstrosities, a Wisdom (Medicine) check
is required to harvest the material without destroying it, for Aberrations and Constructs, an Intelligence (Arcana) check is required, and for Plants
an Intelligence (Nature) check is required. Exotic Harvesting takes 10 minutes. At your GM's discretion, it may take longer for larger creatures.

remnants header.header: Applicable Targets: Celestials, Elementals, Fiends, Incorporeal Undead

remnants main text.text:
Some creatures typically do not leave behind corpses. While these most often disappear without a trace, sometimes they will leave behind a fragment
of the magical forces that powered them as a remnant, in the form of a reagent or essence. These are less likely to result in a crafting item, but don't
require any check to gather it successfully. Gathering remnants is simple to do, and requires only 1 minute.

gathering text.text:
Materials can simply be found growing in
the wild. When traveling at a slow pace
through wilderness for 8 hours, you can
make a gathering check, but you have
disadvantage to harvest. If you dedicate
8 hours to gathering, you can make two
checks, or harvest one non-essence item
of your choice on the table, or 1d12 of
any trivial item (DC 8).
You can Gather Reagents with a
Herbalism kit (Wisdom) check, kit not
required. You can Search for Materials
with a Survival (Strength, Dexterity, or
Wisdom) check. You can Hunt Game
with a Survival (Dexterity or Wisdom)
check.

main text.text:
Alchemy Overview:
 • Decide you want to brew a potion
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your alchemist's supplies to brew it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Intelligence or Wisdom modifier (your choice) + your
   proficiency bonus with alchemist's supplies
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   potion is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
These crafting checks must be consecutive.
Crafting without alchemist's supplies gives disadvantage.
You can use proficiency with a herbalism kit while crafting
potions of healing, potions of poison, and antitoxins.

Poisoncraft Overview:
 • Decide you want to craft a poison
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your poisoner's kit to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Intelligence or Wisdom modifier (your choice) + your
   proficiency bonus with a poisoner's kit
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   poison is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
These crafting checks do not need to be consecutive.
Crafting without a poisoner's kit gives disadvantage.

Blacksmithing Overview:
 • Decide you want to smith something
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your blacksmith's tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Strength modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   blacksmith's tools
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   object is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Crafting without smith's tools is impossible, but makeshift
tools gives disadvantage.

minor options text.text:
A blacksmith can do minor crafts over 2 hours by
expending 5 gp of materials.
   They can maintain a number of weapons or sets of
armor equal to their proficiency bonus, granting each
weapon or armor a d6 Quality Die.
   For a weapon this can be rolled and added to an attack
or damage roll. For armor it can be rolled when hit with an
attack, to reduce the damage by the amount rolled. Rolling
this die requires no action, but it is expended.
   The blacksmith can modify armor or a weapon. They
can turn a set of plate into half plate or breastplate, or
refit a set of heavy or medium armor to fit a smaller user.
   Modifying a weapon requires a DC 14 check, on a fail
the weapon is damaged and has a -1 penalty to its attack
rolls until fixed. They can weight a weapon giving it the
heavy and two-handed property. They can remove the
heavy property, reducing its damage dice by d2. They can
add the light property to a non-heavy weapon, reducing
its damage dice by d2. They can silver the weapon with
5 silver scraps (10 scraps for two-handed weapons).
   The blacksmith can additionally repair damaged
weapons or armor.

modifiers text.text:
Crafting a weapon or armor out of a non-standard
material gives a Material Modifier, which modifies the DC
and bestows slight changes to the item. The smith can
additionally add any Crafting Modifiers they know,
changing the DC and further modifying the item.

items: No Stealth penalty or Strength requirement
text:
Fragile weapons break on an attack roll of 1 against non-Fragile armored targets
Fragile armor breaks against a critical strike from a non-Fragile weapon
Mithril: Reduces the enchanting DC by 4, counts as having 1 common essence

Masterwork: Failing a crafting roll for Masterwork doesn't cause a failure, but the resulting
   weapon is only a Masterwork if all crafting rolls pass the Masterwork DC
Damage Reduction reduces non-magical bludg., pierc., and slash. damage (min 1)

main text.text:
Cooking Overview:
 • Decide you want to cook something
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your cook's utensils to cook it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   cook's utensils
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   meal is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
These crafting checks must be consecutive.
Crafting without cook's utensils gives disadvantage.
All meals require a heat source to cook.

Enchanting Overview:
 • Decide you want to enchant something
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your arcana skill to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Intelligence modifier + your Arcana* proficiency bonus
*Psionic enchantments use your Psionic proficiency bonus
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   object is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.

replacing spell scrolls.text:
Replacing Spell Scrolls:
A crafter can replace a spell scroll in an enchantment with
the ability to cast that spell. They must cast that spell for
each crafting check they make on that item. They take a
level of exhaustion for each time this technique is used to
replace a crafting check. A single caster can only replace
one spell scroll for an item, but multiple casters can
replace multiple spell scrolls, incurring the same penalties
upon themselves while assisting you.

1 very rare divine essence
1 very rare primal essence

1 very rare divine essence

main text.text:
Scrollscribing Overview:
 • Decide you want to make a scroll of a spell
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your calligraphy tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   calligraphy tools (if proficient with Arcana)
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   scroll is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Optionally, clerics can use Wisdom in place of
Intelligence, relying on Religion instead of Arcana.
Scrolls created in this way are called scriptures, and may
only be able to be used by others of the same faith.
Crafting without calligraphy tools is impossible.

Wand Whittling Overview:
 • Decide you want to make a lesser or greater wand
 • A lesser wand is based on a single spell, a greater spell
   is a collection of spells or abilities
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your woodcarver's tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Dexterity modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   woodcarver's tools (if proficient with Arcana)
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   wand is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Crafting without woodcarver's tools is impossible.

Leatherworking Overview:
 • Decide you want to leatherwork something
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your leatherworker's tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Dexterity modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   leatherworker's tools
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   object is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Crafting without leatherworker's tools gives disadvantage.

Tinkering Overview:
 • Decide you want to tinker something
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your tinker's tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   tinker's tools
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   object is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Crafting without tinker's tools gives disadvantage.
Heat from a fire or forge may be necessary.

Woodcarving Overview:
 • Decide you want to woodcarve something
 • Aquire the materials needed
 • Use your woodcarver's tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Dexterity modifier + your proficiency bonus with
   woodcarver's tools
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   object is done
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Crafting without woodcarver's tools gives disadvantage.

Runecarving Overview:
 • Decide you want to carve a rune onto something
 • Gather materials for the rune carving
 • Use your related tools to craft it
 • For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of 1d20 + your
   Wisdom or Intelligence modifier + your proficiency
   bonus with the related tools
 • On a success, mark 2 hours of completed time until the
   rune is carved
 • On a failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has
   been made. If you fail 3 times in a row the crafting is a
   failure and all materials are lost.
Crafting without the related tool is impossible.

runic traditions.text:
Rune carving comes in two traditions, each requiring
different tools and abilities.

Ancient Tradition:
The runes of Giants, Dwarves, and other cultures. Use
Wisdom to carve Ancient Runes, and select your tool
from Mason's Tools or Painter's Supplies.

Academic Tradition:
The runes of Elves, mages, and scholars. Use Intelligence
to carve Academic Runes, and select your tool from
Calligrapher's Supplies or Woodcarver's Tools.
